The symptoms and endoscopy findings suggest that the patient has VIPoma, a rare neuroendocrine tumor that secretes vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), causing diarrhea and flushing. Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that can inhibit the secretion of VIP and is the most appropriate medication for management. Metoclopramide and omeprazole are not effective for VIPoma, and metronidazole is used for bacterial infections.

Octreotide is a somatostatin analog that can reduce the secretion of vasoactive substances and help control symptoms in patients with carcinoid syndrome. Metoclopramide is a prokinetic drug used for gastroparesis, omeprazole is a proton-pump inhibitor used for acid reflux, and metronidazole is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections. None of these are appropriate for the management of carcinoid syndrome.
